Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop is to foster discussions among the leading researchers toward a roadmap for foundational research in cybersecurity and cyberspace over the next ten years with a broad perspective, taking into consideration relevant science, technology, and policy issues, and with an emphasis on the social sciences and education. The previous ten years has seen cyberspace become ubiquitous and essential for modern life. It has also seen the emergence of a criminal cyber-underground and exfiltration of corporate and personal information on a massive scale. The next ten years will likely see equally dramatic change too.

This proposal is for support of this workshop, for travel, and for post-workshop report preparation and publication.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2014 SaTC CyberSpace 2025 Workshop grant proposal funded Vanderbilt University to support the organization and logistics required to assemble SaTC community stakeholders including representatives from academia, industry, government, and independent research institutions for a two-day event that was held on Tuesday, April 22 -Wednesday, April 23,  2014 at the Waterview Conference Center in the Rosslyn Community of Arlington, Virginia. This was an invitation-only workshop, co-chaired by Karl Levitt (UC-Davis) and Patrick Lincoln (SRI International). There were 80 registered participants of which 79 attended.

Logistics included securing and coordinating the meeting space, hotel lodging, catering, registration, audio visual and other elements required to make this conference a success. Meeting organization included supporting the coordination of the meeting program, including the plenary, plenary panel, breakout, and dinner sessions as well as building and maintaining the program website.

The workshop fostered discussions toward a roadmap for foundational research in cybersecurity and cyberspace over the next 10-15 years with a broad perspective, taking into consideration relevant science, technology, and policy issues, and with an emphasis on the social sciences and education.

The workshop was motivated by the far-reaching possibilities of cyber-enabled systems in society that advances in science and technology may enable. Discussions centered on what is possible and the foundational research challenges over the next decade towards addressing those challenges while mitigating undesirable consequences. Examples of questions to motivate and set the stage for the workshop included:

  • What cyber-future scenarios make you hopeful or not hopeful?

  • What convergences of technologies and events make some scenarios more likely?

  • What new multi-spectrum threats might challenge a highly cyber-enabled society?

  • What social, behavioral, economic, and policy challenges do the scenarios pose?

  • What strategies and incentives may accelerate research and transition?

The overriding question for this workshop was - what innovative, foundational, and long-range research is needed to address the significant cyber threats to an ever cyber-dependent society.

The program consisted of three main kinds of sessions:

  • Keynotes: The event had two keynote speakers appearing one per day.  The day-one Dinner Keynote was given by “Eugene Spaf” Spafford (Purdue), on the following topic: Re-Learning Security Lessons Forgotten. Dr. Farnam Jahanian (NSF CIS Director at the time of the workshop and currently the Interim President of CMU) provided the day-two keynote.
  • Panels – Five panel sessions were programmed over the two-day workshop to provide diverse perspectives on topics of interest to SaTC community stakeholders. These included panel sessions on Stakeholders, Lessons Learned from Previous Studies, Science and Technology, Social, Behavioral, and Economic Science and Technology, and Discussion on Next Steps. We aimed to select panelists from a variety of SaTC backgrounds, institutions, and research areas.
  • Breakouts – A major element of this workshop was its focus on breakout sessions. Three program topic sessions on Stakeholder Perspectives, Science and Technology, and Social, Behavioral, and Economic S&T were also the topics of the corresponding breakout sessions.

The breakouts on Stakeholder Perspectives were designed get diverse perspectives from SaTC stakeholders representing industry, government, academia, workforce, smart technologies, and the general citizenry. The Science and Technology breakouts were programmed by the following subtopics: Clean Slate/Design Tools& Techniques, Convergence of Technologies, Democratization of Technology, Future Tools, and The Privacy/Security Nexus. The breakouts on Social, Behavioral, and Economic S&T focused on the subtopics of Challenges to Privacy, Future Scenarios/Geo-Political Changes, Identity Management in the Future, and Social Media and Ethics. Each set of breakout sessions resulted with summary reports being provided at the full plenary session.

The full program agenda with links to slide presentations, speaker bios, approved videos, and calls for papers results can be found at the workshop website at https://cps-vo.org/group/CyberSpace2025.
